poem:
### Ode to Gravy

Brown comfort, poured  
over mash and meat—  
not jus, not glaze,  
but a warm embrace.  
A river runs along the plate,  
binding pie to memory.  
Homely, unembellished,  
it lingers—  
an echo of Sunday  
and hearth,  
where simple becomes  
sublime.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It is not jus. It is not a glaze. It is gravy!’ Britain’s gift to the world finally gets the love it deserves Pub roasts, grannies, Sunday lunch, Ah! Bisto!: gravy triggers nostalgic food memories for Britons like little else. But unlike complex French sauces, for example, gravy is brown and plain, not gastronomic alchemy. Its homely bedfellows – potatoes and pies – have had fancy makeovers, but gravy’s potential hasn’t been much exploited on". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
